docs.lead_paragraph: IT IS MIDNIGHT OVER THE ATLANTIC AND the President of the United States is wide awake. He is returning from an extraordinary antiterrorism summit in Egypt and a 24-hour visit to Israel, where he was praised as the peacemaking hope of the world. He has eaten a dinner of grilled shrimp and teriyaki linguine, played five games of hearts, watched a movie and talked to reporters traveling aboard Air Force One for a solid hour on topics from Arafat to Farrakhan, from the V-chip to the N.C.A.A. Now, having exhausted his aides in the forward cabins, he is pacing the length of the darkened Boeing 747, working out a charley horse and waiting for the 12-hour flight to end so he can get home to the White House and sleep. In blue jeans, sneakers and leather bomber jacket, he appears from the galley at the tail of the giant plane, ambling up the aisle of the cramped press section, which contains the 14 reporters, photographers and cameramen in the rotating pool that covers him constantly.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK is a city of paradoxes, of vast, public places and hermetic enclaves, of private, almost anonymous spaces that we appropriate as our own. It's as if every walker in the city had his own mental map of the urban zone, engraved with his own private landscape. We fix upon a patch of park, or a room in a museum where few ever seem to venture, or maybe a restaurant in an out-of-the-way spot or an unusual store, and they become sanctuaries that we take possession of as our own. In this way, the city becomes personal as well as public. These are places to which we return again and again, drawn to them as if to say, This city is my own: I claim it here.

headline.main: Finding Personal Spaces in Public Places
